As regards the assets in the Australian Capital Territory, I take the view that we would look closely at the actions of the Builders Labourers Federation in the post- deregistration period and, if some action was warranted in respect of its funds, we would consider taking that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to recent Press reports regarding the Star Wars program or, to be more correct, the strategic defence initiative. How does the Minister propose to respond to the letter sent to him by United States Secretary of Defense Weinberger on 27 March of last year which invited Australian participation in the SDI research program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot of misunderstanding about the letter that Mr Weinberger sent to me last year. One is that the letter contained some sort of deadline which the Government has failed to meet. In fact, as Mr Weinberger himself made clear in a subsequent letter, there is no such deadline, nor has there been any pressure from the United States for a response.

ANSWER.PARA: The second misperception, even more important, concerns what exactly it was that the letter was asking for. It has tended to be assumed that Mr Weinberger was asking for specific undertakings to participate in particular SDI research projects. That is not so. The United States has requested us to enter into broadly-based negotiations to establish the ground rules for any Australian participation in SDI-funded research. Such an agreement would cover such issues as security, intellectual property and commercial implications. Negotiations on these matters with the United States Government have been completed or are under way with a number of countries, including the United Kingdom, West Germany and Japan.

The Australian Government does not endorse the SDI concept, and as a result we will not be entering into negotiations of any sort to establish an umbrella agreement of this kind for SDI research. This will preclude Australian participation in research funded under the SDI program. The United States Government is aware of the Government's position, both on SDI as a whole and on Mr Weinberger's invitation to enter negotiations on an umbrella agreement. Cabinet will consider how best to handle any remaining areas of uncertainty which may arise, but that consideration will strictly conform to the basic policies which I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Housing and Construction. I refer the Minister to the categorical assurance he gave to this Parliament prior to the South Australian election that neither he, nor the Prime Minister nor the Treasurer had any intention whatsoever of lifting the housing interest rate ceiling as it would be completely wrong to do so. I ask the Minister, will he now give a categorical assurance that neither he, nor the Prime Minister nor the Treasurer has any intention of lifting the interest rate ceiling on existing home loans? In view of the previous broken promises on new home loans, what does he think such an assurance is worth?
—We will not be lifting the ceiling for existing loans.
—Lies!
—Order! The honourable member for Barker will withdraw his interjection.
—I withdraw.

—Early this year it became apparent to me that the high interest rates and the ceiling on savings banks loans were having an effect upon the flow of funds into housing. As the House will be aware, I have put submissions to the Government which were based on the figures of the Indicative Planning Council on 5 March.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin has asked a question and I presume that he wants to hear the answer. I ask the House to come to order and listen to the answer.

—The IPC after meeting on 5 March informed me that it expected about 122,500 starts in 1986-87 upon an assumption that the savings banks would lend approximately $4.9 billion in 1986-87 from a total of $9.5 billion by trading banks, savings banks and building societies. Over the ensuing weeks since then as this matter has been under consideration by the Government, the savings banks have been consistently revising their prediction downwards, until in early April they informed the Treasurer that we could expect about $3 billion in lending for 1986-87, which implied a base of about 100,000 starts during 1986-87. It was against that background and in the knowledge that if we were to introduce the package that we subsequently announced last Wednesday we could kick up starts from 100,000 to 135,000 and, in the process, save 50,000 jobs, that we made the announcement. I repeat: The banks gave the latest information to the Treasurer in early April and Cabinet considered the matter the next day.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OUT AND ABOUT ROAD SAFETY CAMPAIGN

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport a question relating to the Out and About road safety campaign initiated by him for Australian school children. In view of the fact that road crashes are the single biggest killer of children under 16 years of age and in view of the outstanding response to the Out and About campaign, will the Government be providing additional stocks of kits for schools? Will the program be repeated next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The issue he raises is one of great importance to this Government and, I believe, to this Parliament-to all members on both sides of the House. Road crashes are the greatest single killer of children in this country. In 1984 some 357 were killed. Last year the figure dropped to 318. Within that figure, 43 per cent were passengers, 34 per cent were pedestrians and 15 per cent were on bicycles.

ANSWER.PARA: The responsibility for dealing with this grave situation rests with three groups: Parents in the home and how they educate their children in the use of roads, road vehicles and how they travel; schools and how they include in their curriculum the issue of road safety education; and, more broadly, the community itself. I refer to the responsibility of motorists to watch out for other road users, particularly children.

The specific purpose of the Out and About campaign is to communicate with parents, teachers and children. Hence, I have written to each member of this chamber, forwarding to each of them a kit. I say that for the benefit of those honourable members who have not looked at their mail.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got it a month ago.
—If the honourable member is not interested, that is his decision. There are a number of items in that kit.
—We read it all a month ago.

—Good. I am very pleased about that. The honourable member is progressing. The kit includes the parents' guide to safety, the primary teachers' guide to road safety and two other road safety books for different age groups of children. I am very encouraged by the excellent response to this initiative from honourable members on both sides of the chamber, apart from a few exceptions.

ANSWER.PARA: Road safety and the reduction in the number of road casualties are issues that transcend the political scene. This Government has made it a major priority, but so has this Parliament, particularly through its Standing Committee on Transport Safety with the participation of honourable members from both sides of the House on that Committee. If we are to reduce the level of casualties, we have to strengthen that response from both sides of the Parliament and out in the broader community.

I say also that the response from schools has been excellent. Quite a number of schools are now taking the issue into their curriculum. They are responding with requests for more of the kits, and they are getting out and spreading the message.

I thank all members of this chamber for the effort and initiative that they have put into the campaign. As members of parliament, we are in an excellent position to be able to spread the message on this very important issue. I congratulate the honourable member for Eden-Monaro on the initiative that he has shown in this matter. I can say to him that the kits have had to go to a reprint. The new edition will be due in a matter of a few weeks and, certainly, next year we will rerun the campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction will recall that since the Prime Minister promised that interest rates would fall and would keep falling farmers, small businessmen and home owners have been driven to poverty by his Government's high interest rates policy. The Minister, within his bailiwick, would know that a family with a building society loan for $50,000 is now paying an additional $75 a month. Will the Minister tell the 500,000 Australians with building society loans why they are different from people with bank home loans? Will their interest rates go up again? Why have his Government's policies failed? Why should his word, the Prime Minister's word or the Treasurer's word ever be believed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will be aware that it is the responsibility of Federal governments to control or not control ceilings on savings banks' interest rates and it is the responsibility of State governments to monitor the performance of building societies and control or not control their interest rates. I draw it to the House's attention that over the last few months, at a time when this Government has steadfastly held the cap on savings banks' interest rates, we have faced the situation that the very State governments and permanent building societies who were exhorting us to keep the cap on the savings bank rates have in fact been busily authorising under their own responsibilities some increases in permanent building society rates, decisions which in themselves have helped to exacerbate the outflow of funds from savings banks to permanent building societies. As a matter of fact, this position is illustrated by the fact that in the month of January the savings banks experienced a rundown of $680m in their deposits base, while the permanent building societies held their position.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude my answer on this note: The decision we took last Wednesday in effect restored the competitive position of the banks vis-a-vis the permanent building societies. We will be monitoring the position regarding savings banks and the permanent building societies but at the moment we see it primarily as a matter for State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of claims made by the Leader of the Opposition on the Sunday program that a coalition government would abolish Medicare, that this would save up to $3 billion and that such a step would result in `better and cheaper' health care? Can the Minister inform the House of the drastic effects of cutting $3 billion from the health budget as has been suggested by the Leader of the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I did not see the program on which the Leader of the Opposition appeared but his remarks have been brought to my notice. Two points can be made about his remarks. First of all, they once again show one of those interesting rifts that are appearing in the Opposition on its policy side. The honourable member for Barker has been running around the country offering the soft option, telling people that they will be able to opt out of Medicare. The Leader of the Opposition makes it clear, by implication in that interview, that he will get rid of Medicare, that he will abolish it. Of course, some of his supporters back him up. We leave it to the Opposition to settle these policy differences. I am sure that will provide fun for all of us.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point that can be made about the statement of the Leader of the Opposition is that it was made by someone who is economically illiterate about health matters. He could not save $3 billion even by abolishing Medicare and removing all subsidies for pensioners and the disadvantaged. Let me do the sums for him so that they can be quite clear. At the moment the total cost of Medicare, that is, Medicare benefits, Medicare administration and Medicare payments to the States, is $3.7 billion. However, one has to take away from that the levy which raises this year $1.3 billion, so the most the Leader of the Opposition could save would be $2.4 billion. Of course, in that $2.4 billion there is $1 billion for medical benefits for pensioners and the disadvantaged. I think that, when he comes to his senses, even he will not argue that that $1 billion should be saved. That leaves him with a total possible saving of $1.4 billion. But having got rid of Medicare, he will have to subsidise private insurance. If he subsidises it at the rate the Fraser Government did in 1981, that is, provide 30c in every dollar for private health contributions, he would lose the rest of that saving. He would finish up with a saving of approximately $1m. The figures are now on the record. They may be examined by those on the other side and they can deal with these kinds of extreme statements that they have made.

Not only will no savings be made, but in fact he will, as a result of these acts, have put the cost of medical insurance beyond the reach of most Australian families. For instance, by getting rid of Medicare he will have left a private health contribution rate for a family of between $25 and $30 a week, that is, between $1,300 and $1,560 a year. That would certainly not be cheaper or fairer for the great majority of Australians. What these people on the other side have yet to realise is that Medicare is not only the fairest and most efficient but also the most popular health scheme this country has had in the last 10 years.

The Leader of the Opposition has said that health will be an issue at the next election. We welcome that because our latest surveys show that Medicare, with a 61 per cent satisfaction rate, is the most popular health scheme in the last 10 years. All those opposite have behind them is those five schemes-one scheme every two years. The surveys show that 90 per cent of the Australian people value the service delivered to them through the Medicare offices. So we welcome both the idiotic calculations and the decision to fight the next election on Medicare.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Housing and Construction remember the statement by the Treasurer only four months ago that the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling on bank home loans would remain for `the indefinite future' since `the banks have had a meal' and therefore could afford to continue to operate under the existing interest rate ceiling? Why did the Government in its decision of last week ignore the interests of the building societies when formulating its interest subsidy scheme? What will he do about those existing building society--
—We have already answered that question.
—What will the Minister do-
—Didn't we answer it the first time around, Madam Speaker?
—Order!
—Madam Speaker, the Prime Minister regards this matter as being trivial.
—Coming from you, yes.
—Order! The Prime Minister will cease interjecting.

—What will the Minister do about the existing building society borrowers, referred to this morning by the honourable member for Lilley, whose resources are stretched to the limit and who risk the loss of their homes following the Government's decision of last week?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I recognise that everyone is a bit steamed up tonight, but could I please have silence while the question is being answered? After all, you have asked the question. I call the Treasurer.
—Madam Speaker, before the Treasurer answers that question, would you mind explaining to the Opposition side of the House the basis of that comment of yours?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very obvious that housing loan interest rates are interesting everybody, both within and without the House. I understand that people are interested in the questions and the answers. May I please have silence while the questions are being asked and while the answers are being given.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot help but like them, Madam Speaker. The Opposition seems to misunderstand what the Government has done. Opposition members have trouble getting the penetration. In fact, what has happened in the building industry and in the savings banking system is that the rate of decline in the deposits of savings banks has been very marked, and the Government could not let a position obtain where the banks continued to see those deposits haemorrhage, and to have its principal housing finance lending institutions essentially taken out of the market-place. The decision does two things. It allows the banks to charge what they need to charge to attract deposits for new lending, which is a position which puts them now into some sort of symmetry with permanent building societies, which have largely enjoyed that position in the past, but the subsidy to banks goes only to underpin the deposit base which is itself underpinning existing mortgages.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that the subsidy is of only about 0.6 per cent in terms of what the Government will be paying, the fact of the matter is that the margin which the permanent building societies have enjoyed and the level of their deposit rates have been such as to keep their deposits growing much more strongly than those of banks. In fact, savings bank deposits have grown by only 2.3 per cent in the 12 months to January 1986, whereas permanent building societies' deposits grew at 11 per cent. The reason why permanent building societies' deposits grew at 11 per cent is that the societies were more competitive-and if they have been more competitive in terms of their deposits and have been able to lend their deposits, the implication in the honourable gentleman's question falls to the ground. The implication is that in some way the subsidy to the banking system is discriminating in favour of banks, whereas the banking system has suffered by virtue of the fact that there is a ceiling on existing loans. The ceiling on the existing loans has meant that banks have not been able to recover in the market deposit rates which they might otherwise have attracted but which permanent building societies have been able to attract, and, because the permanent building societies have been able to attract those deposit rates and to lend, the societies have remained with a rate of deposits which is much stronger-five times stronger-than that of the savings banks, and that is why the assumptions in the honourable gentleman's question fall to the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of assertions made by the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Community Services, Mr Bob Katter, Jr, that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs committed the Commonwealth to funding the difference between wages paid by the Queensland Government to Aboriginal people working in reserve communities and the relevant award rates? Did the Minister make such a commitment? If so, has he now reneged on that arrangement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the assertions made by the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Community Services. He is, of course, mistaken. There has been a continuing problem on Queensland reserves which is well known to the Queensland Government and would be well known to members of this Parliament; that is, that on almost every Queensland reserve award wages are not paid for award work. I would have thought that a government which was concerned to talk about the maintenance of law would not want to be continually in breach of its own laws and continually in a situation where award wages were not being paid.

ANSWER.PARA: The commitment that I was prepared to make was that, as deeds of grant in trust were being issued to Queensland reserve communities, the Commonwealth would be prepared to enter into arrangements with the Queensland Government for a joint working party which consisted of representatives of the Queensland Government, the Commonwealth and the communities and, as Aboriginal communities took over control of the economic and social resources within their own communities, the Commonwealth would be prepared not merely to assist in that arrangement, but to see that they were in a position to be able to comply with the laws of the State and see that award wages were paid. That was the commitment. It was never a general commitment to pick up for what has been a continuing and wilful failure of the Queensland Government over the years. Although it talks about equality between all Queenslanders, the Queensland Government has consistently refused to see that award wages are paid on Aboriginal reserve communities for award work. Of course, the processes of the Queensland Parliament are such that there is no committee of the Parliament to make an objective examination of the resources that are earned by Aboriginal people to see where the money has actually been expended in those communities and to see that the laws of the State of Queensland are being observed by the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his broken promises on the assets test, the lump sum taxation on superannuation, the capital gains tax, interest rates, the dollar, petrol prices, inflation, the trilogy and the creation of 10,000 traineeships under the Priority One scheme, culminating last week in the wilful breaking of the promise made by him only two weeks ago not to lift the home loan interest rate ceiling. I ask the honourable gentleman: Which promise does he intend to break next?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members to understand that it took the Leader of the Opposition 19 days to think up that one. Devastating, is it not? The facts are these: First, let us dispose of the entitlement of the Leader of the Opposition to address himself to this area at all. This is the man who perpetrated upon the taxpayers of this country the greatest fraud in its history. He gave them a tax cut and then grabbed it back from them. This individual has rapidly become the most pathetic figure in the history of Australian politics. Never before have we had the pathetic spectacle of a Leader of the Opposition saying that the only thing that can save his position as the Leader of his Party is the country falling into a recession. That is what the man has said! He has said that the only thing that can save his leadership is the country falling into a recession.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no wonder, therefore, that, when this Government makes the decisions which ensure that this country will have high and sustainable economic growth, with sustainable levels of inflation and growing levels of employment, when this Government makes the decisions necessary to achieve that objective, this temporary Leader of the Opposition expresses his disappointment. I simply say to the Leader of the Opposition and to those behind him that this Government will continue to take those decisions which are necessary to sustain this country on the path of high economic growth and growing levels of employment which distinguish this country under this Government from the worst recession in 50 years inflicted upon it by the gentleman opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action has the Australian Government taken to follow up allegations of child labour in the Philippines, contained in a report on Channel 9's Sunday program in November 1985? What results, if any, have been obtained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Sydney raised the question of child labour in the Philippines on 19 November in this House. His question followed a report on Channel 9's Sunday program, which depicted the large scale use of child labour in the Philippines fishing industry. The Australian Embassy in Manila carried out investigations into the allegations raised in the program following the issue being raised in the Parliament by the honourable member for Sydney. Embassy officials raised the matter with officials of the Ministry of Labour and Employment, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the International Labour Organisation. Officials also talked to the American broadcasting company who made the program, the crew of the research vessel Soll, and a local member of parliament. Following questions raised by Australian Embassy officials, the ILO has given funds to the Ministry of Labour and Employment to start an investigation into the alleged practices shown in the report. The ILO is currently finalising a report on child labour in the Philippines. The Embassy in Manila will continue to liaise with the ILO on the results of its investigations.

ANSWER.PARA: I congratulate the honourable member for Sydney for having raised this matter in the Parliament and similarly congratulate the Sunday program on Channel 9, which brought the matter before public attention in the first instance. As a result of that conjunction of initiatives, action is now being taken on this matter. I hope that the final result will lead to an amelioration of the working conditions for children in the Philippines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Housing and Construction to the Prime Minister's statement last week that new housing starts would have fallen to 100,000 or less in 1986-87, but that the Government's decision to remove the ceiling for new home loans will now guarantee 135,000 new housing starts. Can the Minister explain why he thinks the Government's housing package will increase the number of housing starts by 35,000 when the Master Builders Federation of Australia believes the package will increase housing starts by only 10,000? Does the Minister now regard the Prime Minister's 1984 election promise that there would be 145,000 new starts each year while the Hawke Government remained in office as now being inoperative and adding to his Prime Minister's ever growing litany of broken promises?

—The first thing that we should understand is that in the last year of the previous Government there were 105,000 starts. After two years under this Government the annual figure was 152,700 starts. All I can say is that members of the Opposition are a bunch of slow learners. That fact is evident to everyone. Seeing that they are such slow learners, let me repeat to them the mathematics of what I have just said.
—This is better than the movies. It really is. It took you 12 months to learn about the ceiling.

—The Leader of the Opposition is Mr Thirteen and a half per cent. He leads a front bench of slow learners who think they are on to something, but they are not. I said, in answer to the first question that I was asked today, that on 5 March the Indicative Planning Council had indicated that, from a base of nearly $5 billion in savings bank loans in 1986-87 out of a total of $9.5 billion, we would be looking at about 122,500 starts, but that that figure would fall during the June and September quarters to an annualised rate of about 115,000. We then found that three weeks later the banks were saying that they would be lending about $3 billion, so we would be looking at a base not of $9.5 billion, but of about $7 billion. If we took no action, the figure could be down to as low as 100,000 starts, at an annualised rate during the June and September quarters. For every 10,000 housing starts, about 15,000 jobs are involved, either directly or as a spin-off. A figure of $6 billion from savings banks instead of $3 billion during 1986-87, means that about $10 billion to $10 1/2 billion would be available from trading banks, savings banks and permanent building societies during 1986-87. It is a perfectly rational assumption that the number of housing starts would increase from 100,000 to 135,000, thus saving 50,000 jobs. I quite understand that such simple arithmetic is beyond the capacity of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Thirteen and a half per cent, but that is the way it is.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Are a number of economic indicators supporting and reinforcing the Government's long term economic strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the honourable member's question is yes. But I owe it to the honourable member to add, at least at slight length, to that answer. The facts are that on the basis of the latest national accounts, non-farm product growth over the 2 1/2 years from June 1983 to December 1985 was 15 per cent, or at an annualised rate of 5.9 per cent. That is double the sort of pathetic achievement that existed under the previous Government. That fundamental statistic shows the truth of the implication of the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: In the same period 600,000 jobs have been created. Since June last year, employment growth has been 3.3 per cent, which sustains the analysis of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development that the employment performance of the Australian economy was the best of all OECD countries. Looking at the level of non-farm gross domestic product growth, the level of employment growth and the fact that we have weathered significant devaluation and are now moving on to a lower inflation path, these fundamentals of growth, employment and inflation indicate that this Government has continued to do what it promised to deliver when the other mob were thrown out rightly in 1983; that is, we said that we would turn this economy around. We have done that. That is why one ceiling that certainly will not be lifted is the 13.5 per cent rating of the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Housing and Construction to the fact that any forecast of housing activity must include an assumption about the prevailing level of interest rates. In view of this, can the Minister tell the House what specific interest rate assumptions underlie the Government's 135,000 figure for new housing starts in 1986-87?

—The assumptions of the Indicative Planning Council, headed by Professor Gruen and with representatives from industry, on 5 March were that there would be a sustainable fall in interest rates, particularly from the June quarter onwards.
—Ha, ha!

—That is what the Indicative Planning Council said. Because our projections are based on the IPC assumptions, and the pick-up arising from the $3 billion-plus increased lending that will be generated by our package, the assumptions underlying our forecasts are the same as those of the IPC.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report relating to the proposed construction of the National Bicentennial Science Centre within the parliamentary zone.
Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—I believe that I have been seriously misrepresented by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) as shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, in his media statement of 26 March 1986. His statement reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Peacock, today called on the Prime Minister to dissociate himself and his Party from the remarks of the Labor Party backbencher, Mr Peter Staples.

Mr Peacock said that while Mr Staples was an insignificant Labor Backbencher, he was still a member of the Australian Parliament and his remarks could not be ignored. `The effect of Mr Staples' remarks is to support a regime that sponsors terrorism as an instrument of Government policy'.

While the honourable member, for his own sake, stopped short of stating that I support a regime which supports terrorism-in this case Libya and Colonel Gaddafi-his statement quite clearly insinuates that this is the case. I unequivocally reject this assertion-or at best, cheap insinuation-as a gross and insulting misrepresentation of my statement and position. My remarks on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio are available from the Parliamentary Library for all to read. Basically they were limited to the following points. I accused the United States of provoking the incident. Subsequently this accusation has been clearly proven to be correct by reports from a wide variety of sources inside and outside the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will quickly get to the point.

—I was asked whether I believed that Libya's attempt to sink United States ships was entirely justified. I responded by saying that it was not entirely justified because both the United States and Libya were at fault. I have consistently spoken out against terrorism, whatever its forms, whoever the perpetrators.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating the point. He will resume his seat; he has finished his personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—In an article in the Australian on Wednesday, 2 April, under the heading `Pressure mounts to refuse Star Wars research' by Ross Peake I have been misrepresented. In fact, a completely inaccurate report appeared in that article. While Mr Peake quotes me at length over a few paragraphs, which are perfectly correctly, he goes on to say one thing that is totally wrong, which I wish to put before the House. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee is working on the final draft of a report on disarmament and arms control, which will focus heavily on Star Wars.
That is his own assumption and I cannot comment on that. The next paragraph, which is totally inaccurate, reads:
The chairman of the disarmament sub-committee, Mr David Charles (ALP, Vic.), said yesterday that Opposition committee members would probably write dissenting reports from the main recommendation.

I deny completely that I made, to Mr Peake or to anyone else, any statement in regard to that matter. The Parliament will note that that paragraph is not in quotes. Obviously Mr Peake or some sub-editor down the track has either got things back to front or made certain assumptions which are totally incorrect. There are 28 members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, who will make up their minds on a range of matters on disarmament and their decisions will become known only when the report is tabled in Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is starting to debate the subject of personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek your indulgence to raise a question of parliamentary procedure.
—Please proceed.

—As a result of an interchange between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and me, recorded in the Daily Hansard of 19 February 1986 at pages 857 and 858, you made the following statement to the Parliament, as recorded in the Daily Hansard of 20 February 1986 at page 946:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I will not tolerate, from either side, allegations or imputations of a personal nature . . .

Since then your ruling has been tested by members of the Government on at least two occasions, as recorded in Hansard. The efforts of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), recorded on page 1425, to which I protested, resulted in changes to the guidelines for rebroadcasting of parliamentary proceedings and raises the question whether the convention of withdrawing is sufficient redress for more serious breaches of your ruling. The other action, that of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) by interjection, was properly and promptly dealt with by you.

Pages 1717 and 1718 of the Daily Hansard of 20 March 1986 record me protesting about the use of the word `hobos' by the Treasurer in reference to members of the Opposition. The comparison of the level of insults on a scale of one to 10 of `hobos', `harlots', `dogs returning to their vomit' or the suggestion that a member has welshed on a marriage contract is clearly up to the Chair, but I suggest all are equally bad and unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Intellectual hobos.

—The suggestion-it has just been made by the honourable member for Grayndler-that one can be an intellectual hobo is grammatically incorrect and therefore is no excuse. As Hansard records, the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees ruled that my protest at the use of the word `hobo' in this context was not valid. I therefore request, Madam Speaker, that you consider my point of order and rule at your convenience on this point and on whether you will in future accept a simple withdrawal for more flagrant breaches of your ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the issue raised by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey); I was not aware that he was going to raise it. However, I have been concerned, especially since he referred to an incident in which I was involved, about the fact that at the end of an answer to a question which I gave he asked that I withdraw something that he found objectionable. I was not quite sure what he was objecting to. Madam Speaker, you will recall that at the time you said that you did not hear it and in order to facilitate the business of parliament I said that I would withdraw anything that the honourable member for O'Connor found objectionable. Later I felt that he must have been objecting to the remarks I had made about the late Sir Robert Askin.
—No, two members of this House.
—Just a minute. I found it difficult to understand why any honourable member would want remarks about Sir Robert Askin withdrawn. Nevertheless, to facilitate the Parliament and because-
—That is disgusting.
—Just a minute.

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. Earlier this session you made rulings about the standard of conduct of honourable members. I think that the Minister's remarks about the late Premier are really unsatisfactory and should be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—I repeat: Madam Speaker, you said at the time that you did not hear what I had said and I withdrew because the honourable member for O'Connor said that he found something that I had said objectionable. Honourable members are very sensitive about the person to whom I refer.
—Because he is dead and because he showed decency and you don't.
—The honourable member for North Sydney is yelling and screaming. Honourable members should read what is blazoned across the Sydney Morning Herald today.
—Madam Speaker, I was not yelling and screaming. I was raising a point.
—Order! Is the honourable member for North Sydney raising a point of order?
—Yes, I am.
—He will wait until the Chair recognises him.
—Do you recognise me?
—I call the honourable member for North Sydney.
—I am glad to hear you call me.
—I would be glad if the honourable member for North Sydney would wait and observe the courtesies of the House. It is normal to wait until the Chair recognises a member before he speaks.
—I was raising a point of order about the opportunity which has been taken by the Special Minister of State to repeat what he said some time ago about a man who is dead and cannot answer.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—Perhaps a sense of decency may moderate his tongue.
—It is not covered under the Standing Orders. I call the Leader of the House.

—Madam Speaker, I did not repeat anything about the person tonight. I said that I found it difficult to believe that the Opposition wanted what I had said withdrawn: I was not sure what the honourable member for O'Connor wanted withdrawn. However, let me continue. The next day the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair)-he is the Opposition Leader of the House-raised the question about my having withdrawn the statement that I was asked to withdraw although there was some confusion about what had actually been withdrawn and the media repeating it. My attention was drawn to the printed Hansard when it became available which, I think, was the following week when we came back here. If honourable members read the Hansard they would see that at the time I was talking the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) interjected. I responded to him and tried to go on with what I was saying but if honourable members read the Hansard they will see that it appeared that I implied something against the Leader of the Opposition.
—Which you did.

—It certainly appeared that way but I made it perfectly clear the following week after I had seen the Hansard that that was not my intention at all. I made it perfectly clear to the House on two occasions in the following week when this matter became the subject of discussion that I in no way wished to associate the Leader of the Opposition or the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) with what I had said in answer to that question. I think that when we look at the matters raised by the honourable member for O'Connor we will get into some difficulty if on questions of this nature we are asked to withdraw statements which do not affect an honourable member but which affect a person outside the House. Are the Opposition members arguing that an honourable member can say: `I find that objectionable'?
—Surely, that makes it worse.
—Does it? I do not know.
—How can he defend himself?

—I do not know. If the honourable member had watched television tonight he would have seen a discussion on the National Crime Authority when there were all sorts of loose allegations about corruption in politics. We are all subjected to those innuendoes and accusations.
—With names?
—Not under privilege.

—Even under privilege some of these things have been said about people who were not parliamentarians. In some ways parliamentarians, now alive or dead, have wanted to use privilege to name people outside who are not parliamentarians but they do not want themselves named.
—Denis Horgan, John Reid-

—There is a very fine line. Madam Speaker, all I suggest is that when you look at the question raised by the honourable member for O'Connor you also give consideration to the matters I raised about people who are not here-whether they be alive or dead-who may be mentioned in these sorts of discussions because of their previous activities and to whether in fact it is legitimate for a present member of the House to ask the member speaking to withdraw that reference.

—Order! I have listened with interest to what the honourable member for O'Connor raised in the House tonight. I think he will appreciate that it would be quite improper for me publicly to comment on a ruling given by another occupant of the chair. As well as the Speaker there are a number of deputy chairmen and deputy speakers who occupy the chair.
—You are the Speaker.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not comment publicly on rulings given by occupants of the chair. That procedure has been followed by previous Speakers and I think it is one which the House should appreciate. However, I will discuss the matters raised by both the Leader of the House and the honourable member for O'Connor with other occupants of the chair. I just repeat for the honourable member for O'Connor part of the statement I made to the House, which he repeated but did not complete. I said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . I will not tolerate, from either side, allegations or imputations of a personal nature-
Allegations or imputations are fairly clear statements-
particularly remarks or interjections which go into the private lives of members.

I suggest to honourable members that they concentrate on those words. In the hurly burly of politics we often get political compliments or insults thrown across the chamber. I do not expect to bring the House to a total standstill on the exchange of those compliments or those interchanges. However, honourable members will pay regard to my comments on imputations or allegations that intrude into their personal lives.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

not increase or extend fuel taxes; and

The Hawke Labor Government's refusal to pass onto motorists, farmers and small businessmen, and the community as a whole, the full effect of the drop in world oil prices will decrease Australia's competitiveness as a trading nation.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

to desist from airship attacks and seeking a military solution;
to offer refuge under humanitarian and compassionate programs, to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation to any Tamil who has sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
as a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Federal Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirement;
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad inquiry into Australia's income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and,
3. following the report of such a wide inquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Pricing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

- increases the cost of goods to country people,

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

We wish you to rescind the Regulation under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, which prescribes this fee.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

In this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a nuclear test moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The fear, worry and insecurity created in countless Australian families by the Government's high interest rate policies and its confused and inequitable actions on home loans.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places-
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance raised this evening by the Opposition states:

SPEECH.PARA: The fear, worry and insecurity created in countless Australian families by the Government's high interest rate policies and its confused and inequitable actions on home loans.

I note that on a matter of considerable importance to the whole community and a matter of central importance to the Government's economic strategy neither the Treasurer (Mr Keating) nor the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is present in the House to answer-

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor the Minister for Housing and Construction.
—No, neither is the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West).
—I am a good substitute for them all.
—The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is trivialising the matter by making a joke of it, as did the Prime Minister in Question Time-
—Let's get nice and worked up about it all.
—What did the Minister say?
—Order! The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will cease interjecting.

—I wish to make the point very seriously that when a matter of this importance is raised, the Government owes it to the people of Australia, particularly those who are suffering from the Government's high interest rate policies, to have the Ministers responsible here in the chamber to answer. If the Government is not prepared to do that, the Opposition will take the appropriate action to ensure that it does so in the future. Also, I might point out that there is not one single Australian Labor Party member present in the chamber other than the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. There is not a single Labor member other than this junior Minister here to debate a matter of very considerable importance. It is all very well for the Labor Party to get itself into a lather in Caucus this morning about this matter because members are unhappy about the decision made by the Government, yet not one single Labor member, apart from the duty junior Minister, has come here to answer the case. Everyone in Australia who is listening to this debate should understand that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the weekend I spoke to a young man who has a wife and a baby daughter and who bought a home on the western outskirts of Sydney about 12 months ago. The young couple worked out their budget very carefully. The wife had had to give up work in order to look after the newly arrived baby. The husband had calculated that, by taking on extra overtime in his job and by cutting back household expenditures to the bare minimum, the family could just afford the monthly repayments of something over $600 on a building society loan. That was round about the time of the last Federal election when building societies were charging 13 per cent interest on their loans and that is not a small figure. Thirteen per cent is a lot of money. The young couple felt perfectly confident about their plans and their purchase. After all, they had the assurance of the Prime Minister of Australia that the Government placed homes for young people at the top of its priorities. The Prime Minister, in his 1983 policy speech, said:

To provide a stable and adequate flow of funds for housing at affordable interest rates, the Labor Government will maintain interest rate controls on bank mortgage interest rates and extend those controls to building societies.

That was the promise of the Prime Minister in 1983. Our young couple would not have seen the inherent contradiction in that statement. They would not have known that, if interest rates rose above the controlled levels, the flow of funds would dry up. But they trusted the Prime Minister. They also trusted him when he repeated his commitment in his 1984 policy speech in these words:

We pledged ourselves to bring home ownership within the reach of ordinary Australian families-to end that sense of despair and frustration that was beginning to engulf thousands upon thousands of young people seeking their own homes.

Those were the confident words of the Prime Minister seeking re-election only 16 months ago and they would indeed have been reassuring to our young couple embarking on the most important financial decision of their lives which, of course, was buying their own home. The Prime Minister was also categorical about interest rates. In the course of a major address in Adelaide on 20 November 1984, as the election campaign was drawing to a close, the Prime Minister said:
At present the outlook for interest rates is as bright as it has been for more than a decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Prime Minister in the 1984 election campaign only 16 months ago.
—That is not a long time ago.
—As the honourable member for Moreton quite correctly points out, it is not a very long time since that was said. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will continue our work of putting the public finances of this nation back in order and creating the conditions where further interest rate reductions can occur.
The Prime Minister was backed up by this Treasurer who, in a Press release of 15 November 1984, declared:
Continued success against inflation will create conditions conducive to lower interest rates.

Unfortunately for that young couple I spoke about, the election was not long over when interest rates began to rise. Indeed, they were worried that even by the time they had completed the settlement on their home they would already by paying over $40 a month in additional repayments because the building society interest rates had gone up and they have gone up yet again to 14 1/2 per cent since then adding $60 a month to the initial monthly repayment which was the basis of their careful calculations. At this time their budget has been stretched to the very limit and it has not been helped by the husband's wages going into higher tax brackets with overtime and the general rise in prices over recent months. With an inflation rate of over 8 per cent all Australian families, and particularly those on low incomes, are feeling the pinch.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are battling.

—As my friend the honourable member for Franklin has said, they are battling. He is known as the little battler and he would know that these people are really feeling the pinch. So honourable members can imagine the extreme nervousness of this family feeling trapped by the situation but managing at this stage to cling on by its fingernails. Meanwhile, a stream of reassuring statements has been emerging from Government Ministers. On 17 October last year in this House the Minister for Housing and Construction said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say quite firmly again, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said several times in the House, that we do not intend to deregulate housing interest rates, at this time. It is completely the wrong time to do so. We do not intend to lift the ceiling from 13 1/2 per cent.
On 14 November 1985 the Treasurer appeared on AM and we had the following exchange:
Question: You are still insisting are you that the 13.5 per cent ceiling on home loan interest rates should be maintained?
Keating: Yes I am.
Question: And there's no possibility of changing that in the foreseeable future?
Keating: No.

Then there was a whole string of announcements and reassurances from the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and the hapless Minister for Housing and Construction, culminating in the solemn assurances given in this House in response to Opposition questioning just over two weeks ago, on 19 March. The Minister for Housing and Construction declared:
The Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates.
The Prime Minister, only two weeks before the fateful announcement which reversed yet another policy and broke yet another promise, said:

I say to the Leader of the Opposition that the Government will be considering the whole question of the housing industry in Cabinet next week and I say to him, as the Minister for Housing and Construction did, that the Government remains committed to the retention of the ceiling on housing interest rates.

It is a pity that there is no member of the Press Gallery other than the Australian Associated Press here to witness this debate, where the Treasurer is absent and not meeting his responsibility to answer these charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?

—Where indeed is the Treasurer and where is the Press Gallery to watch this debate? We might forgive our young couple clinging to their home on the outskirts of Sydney for starting to have some doubts as to the strength of the Prime Minister's commitment. The Treasurer appeared to be equivocal the following day on the steps of Parliament House, but at Question Time he too repeated this commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened just two weeks later, on 2 April? The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Housing and Construction announced that the ceiling would be lifted for new savings bank loans, a subsidy would be provided to the banks, and the banks only, so that existing savings bank loans could be maintained at 13 1/2 per cent, but that essentially existing building society borrowers could be thrown to the wolves. The young man I spoke to on Saturday was aghast at this decision. He simply could not afford to meet the weekly repayments at a higher rate. Building societies were saying that to meet the additional competition for deposits from the savings banks following the Government's subsidy to the savings banks they would have to raise their deposit and lending rates. Existing building society loans would rise to 15.5 per cent interest. On a $55,000 loan-not uncommon in Sydney for even a modest home-a rate of 15 1/2 would mean an additional monthly cost of $96 in interest charges since the last election only 16 months ago and since the Prime Minister promised that interest rates would not rise. My young couple simply cannot afford that. They are desperately worried that they will have to sell their home and are frightened that so many others will be doing the same and that in the price drop they will lose the value of their initial deposit and hence their whole life savings. All they have worked for is suddenly disappearing before their eyes. They feel cheated, disbelieving and angry.

What answer can the Prime Minister give this young couple? How can they possibly believe ever again a solemn promise from the Prime Minister? The fact is that Hawke promises are worthless promises, broken promises-on interest rates, on taxes, on the trilogy, on petrol prices, on the assets test, on the tax on lump sum superannuation payments, on the value of the Australian dollar, on the 10,000 traineeships under the Priority One scheme; you name the promise, the Prime Minister has broken it.

I am not alone in reflecting the feeling of betrayal amongst so many Australian families. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) is quoted in today's Sydney Morning Herald-this is a Labor member in a marginal seat in Brisbane-as saying:

I believe that if we do not act to protect the interests of thousands of home buyers who have taken out building society loans, we will be guilty of an error of mammoth proportions from which we as a Government, and home buyers may not recover.
Mrs Darling says:

The reality we face is that thousands of couples who have budgeted to their last cent in order to buy a modest home through a building society and who have already had their resources strained to the limit by four increases in repayments over the last year . . . will now face further increases as a result of lifting the ceiling on bank rates.
She goes on to say:
. . . many building society borrowers were paying about $620 a month on $50,000 loans over 30 years, and had seen repayments increase by $60 a month since January.

This is not what I am saying; it is what a member from a marginal Government seat in Brisbane is saying. If I had time I would also refer to what was said by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) from Western Australia, who is listed to speak tonight. He said similar things two weeks ago, just before the Prime Minister gave him the reassurance that the honourable member wanted. The honourable member and his constituents were cheated by the Prime Minister. It is awfully lonely in a marginal seat like Stirling when one is led by a man whose word cannot be trusted. No one can ever trust the Prime Minister or the Treasurer again. Like the Australian dollar under the Prime Minister's administration, his word is devalued.

The main problem is that this Government has failed to produce the economic policies to reduce high interest rates. The Treasurer, like an arsonist who has started a fire, has come in to join the fire brigade to put out the fire in the outhouse, leaving the house itself to burn. The Government, through its economic policies, has failed to reduce interest rates and failed to attack the main part of the problem. It has let down ordinary householders throughout Australia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Treasurer forthwith responding to the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member for Mackellar and directly relating to the high interest rate policies of the Government, that being a matter entirely within the Treasurer's portfolio responsibility.

The Government tonight has shown absolute contempt for every ordinary Australian. Today we had 300 farmers, in dire straits, outside this House. Why? Because the cruelling policies of this Government are grinding them into the dust. We have 500,000 Australians who have borrowed from building societies. Why? Because they thought that the Government meant its word when it said that interest rate ceilings would be maintained. This Government has decided that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not come into the House to respond to debate on a policy for which he is directly responsible. Whether we are talking about small businessmen, the average home owner or the farmer, it is the Treasurer who has responsibility. It was the Treasurer who tonight during Question Time refused to allow the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) to respond to a question from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton); it was the Treasurer who said that it was his responsibility. But when it comes to an opportunity to respond to a matter raised by the shadow Treasurer, when it comes to the shadow Treasurer laying down the ground rules and showing that the Treasurer has misled the Parliament and the people of Australia and has culpably tried to beguile people into thinking that high interest rates are okay, the Treasurer does not bother to come into this place to respond. It is essential that Standing Orders be suspended so that those ordinary Australians can hear from the Treasurer why he has misled them and why they are being called on to pay higher and higher interest rates. Australia is going broke and the Treasurer is leading them in that direction. It is the Treasurer and the Treasurer alone who should come into this place to answer the shadow Treasurer. The honourable member for Mackellar was talking about average Australians, about the average family investing its savings. He was talking about a policy of high interest rates that this Treasurer has introduced into the House, for which this Treasurer is responsible and in respect of which the media is saying what a good fellow he is. Yet, the Treasurer is not even prepared to come into the Parliament and answer to his cause.

It is not good enough that a junior Minister, albeit one who is assisting in the portfolio, should respond in an area in respect of which even at Question Time the Treasurer said: `But I cannot let the Minister for Housing and Construction answer a question-it is too hard. We all saw the mess he made of it'. The Treasurer got up and said: `I have to respond'. It is impossible for the people of Australia to have any confidence in the policies of a government which insists on passing the buck. We want the organ grinder, not the monkey. We want the man who is responsible. We do not want the fellow who is out there playing at the end of the string. This is far too serious a matter for the average Australian. Farmers, small businessmen and home owners have been misled by this Government. They are the people who are suffering. They are essentially the people who have been affected by the promises which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have broken. Yet, the Treasurer will not come into the House to defend what he has done.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is essential that the man who is responsible for this policy should be in this House tonight to answer. It is interesting that the Prime Minister is not here. It is interesting to note that at this moment, this matter having been canvassed in the way it has, five members of the Australian Labor Party are in the chamber and that these members are totally incapable of responding to this matter. We know what happened in the Labor Caucus. We know how the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) feels on the issue. We know how the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) feels on the issue. We know how the people of Australia feel on this issue. Yet, the Government says: `Oh, don't worry'. We know that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) is not prepared to accept this Government's policy. Twenty-eight members of the Caucus moved a motion of no confidence in the Government today.

It is a great government that is not prepared to come into the Parliament and answer its cause. What is happening, of course, is that the responsible Ministers are just running away from it all. They have passed the buck. They are not prepared to tell anyone why high interest rates will continue. They will not tell us why the dollar was allowed to float. They will not tell us about the increase in overseas debt. They will not tell us about the effect of the drought in the bush. They will not talk about the fact that everyone of us who has been falsely led into the belief that living standards will be maintained is being progressively screwed because of the economic policies of the Treasurer who has run for cover and who is not prepared to come into this House and respond to the charges properly made and laid by the shadow Treasurer.

Tonight the shadow Treasurer laid down a list of sins and ills for economic disaster in this country. He laid down a cause for the average Australian. It is interesting that the Government no longer is prepared to tell average Australians what it is going to do. The average Australian knows that he cannot trust the Prime Minister. He knows that he can no longer trust the Treasurer. Every Australian knows that he cannot believe the Minister for Housing and Construction. Every Australian knows that when the monkey comes into the House and the organ grinder stays at home, what we are getting is not the real story but a little bit of a subterfuge. We are being told: `Just tell everybody that everything is all right. We will play the issue down. Don't worry about interest rates. Don't worry about the people of Australia. We read the polls a few weeks ago and we think we will be all right'. The Government should ask members in marginal seats what they think. It should ask the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) who knows that he will lose his seat the next time round. It should ask the honourable member for Lilley, who is not in the chamber, what she thinks about the Treasurer's economic policy. What has happened in Australia is that the Treasurer-

TALK.START.PARA: —She is on the phone, or talk back.

—That is right. She is probably on the phone or talk back. The whole point of this debate tonight is that the Government has shown it neither has the answers nor the integrity to respond to a matter of high economic principle. It is not sufficient for this Parliament to be treated with contempt by the Treasurer. He can run away and say: `Oh, it does not matter. Look, I am too good for that place. I'll go off in my Ferrari and I'll look at my antiques and my clocks and I won't worry about little Australians'. I have a word for the Treasurer. He needs to understand that the average Australian at the moment is worrying about bread and butter. The average farmer is looking at a level of income whereby many of them will run into essentially losses of more than $20,000. The interest bill on rural debt this year will be greater than the total farm income. It is in that climate that the Treasurer says: `I am not going to worry about farmers'. One has only to look at small businessmen, who have been forced to lay off employees, or at the housing area where one has building societies which, we are told, are a lesser breed.
